trans-unit.source: FloodCitiSense is an early warning service for pluvial flooding that is for, but also by citizens and city authorities, and builds upon sensing technologies
trans-unit.target: FloodCitiSense is an early warning service for pluvial flooding that is for, but also by citizens and city authorities, and builds upon sensing technologies

trans-unit.source: By using this app, you can become a valuable contributor to this service by helping to report incidents of pluvial flooding. Although still in a testing phase, future versions will include notifications from the early warning service currently being built as part of the FloodCitiSense project.
trans-unit.target: By using this app, you can become a valuable contributor to this service by helping to report incidents of pluvial flooding. Although still in a testing phase, future versions will include notifications from the early warning service currently being built as part of the FloodCitiSense project.

trans-unit.source: I have read and accept the terms and conditions
trans-unit.target: I have read and accept the terms and conditions

trans-unit.source: If possible add a picture and/or additional information and submit!
trans-unit.target: If possible add a picture and/or additional information and submit!

trans-unit.source: You have already uploaded this Incident!
trans-unit.target: You have already uploaded this Incident!

trans-unit.source: Are you impacted by the flood?
trans-unit.target: Are you impacted by the flood?

trans-unit.source: Don't have an account? Sign up.
trans-unit.target: Don't have an account? Sign up.

trans-unit.source: Forgot your login details? Get help signing in.
trans-unit.target: Forgot your login details? Get help signing in.

trans-unit.source: A problem occurred while trying to communicate with the server. Do you want to try again?
trans-unit.target: A problem occurred while trying to communicate with the server. Do you want to try again?

trans-unit.source: Report the intensity of the rain
trans-unit.target: Report the intensity of the rain

trans-unit.source: No internet connection! Do you want to enable internet and try again?
trans-unit.target: No internet connection! Do you want to enable internet and try again?

trans-unit.source: The operation failed. You need to login first.
trans-unit.target: The operation failed. You need to login first.

trans-unit.source: Develop and review an Emergency Plan
trans-unit.target: Develop and review an Emergency Plan

trans-unit.source: Keep cash on hand to use after the flood if needed
trans-unit.target: Keep cash on hand to use after the flood if needed

trans-unit.source: Take all necessary steps to prevent the release of dangerous chemicals that might be stored on your property
trans-unit.target: Take all necessary steps to prevent the release of dangerous chemicals that might be stored on your property

trans-unit.source: Use plugs to prevent floodwater from backing up into sewer drains, or install flood vents or flood proof barriers
trans-unit.target: Use plugs to prevent floodwater from backing up into sewer drains, or install flood vents or flood proof barriers

trans-unit.source: Stay tuned to local media and community messaging
trans-unit.target: Stay tuned to local media and community messaging

trans-unit.source: Take photos of key areas and critical items. Keep these on a cloud backup
trans-unit.target: Take photos of key areas and critical items. Keep these on a cloud backup

trans-unit.source: Turn off the gas and electricity prior to leaving the property
trans-unit.target: Turn off the gas and electricity prior to leaving the property

trans-unit.source: Keep updated survival and disaster recovery kits
trans-unit.target: Keep updated survival and disaster recovery kits

trans-unit.source: Locate gas main and electrical shut-offs and anchor all fuel tanks
trans-unit.target: Locate gas main and electrical shut-offs and anchor all fuel tanks

trans-unit.source: If time allows, assemble and use sandbags in areas prone to flooding
trans-unit.target: If time allows, assemble and use sandbags in areas prone to flooding

trans-unit.source: Contact your insurance broker to discuss policy, coverage and claims procedures.
trans-unit.target: Contact your insurance broker to discuss policy, coverage and claims procedures.

trans-unit.source: Establish an emergency communication method (phone tree, notification system, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Establish an emergency communication method (phone tree, notification system, etc.)

trans-unit.source: Identify a high ground meeting place
trans-unit.target: Identify a high ground meeting place

trans-unit.source: Elevate equipment, and valuable/perishable items off of the floor
trans-unit.target: Elevate equipment, and valuable/perishable items off of the floor

trans-unit.source: Store all your important documents in labeled sealed plastic bags
trans-unit.target: Store all your important documents in labeled sealed plastic bags

trans-unit.source: Prepare for flooding events and be able to respond in case of flooding
trans-unit.target: Prepare for flooding events and be able to respond in case of flooding

trans-unit.source:
The following guidelines will help you be prepared for a flooding event:
•Develop and review an Emergency Plan.
•Keep updated survival and disaster recovery kits.
•Locate gas main and electrical shut-offs and anchor all fuel tanks.
•If time allows, assemble and use sandbags in areas prone to flooding.
•Contact your insurance broker to discuss policy, coverage and claims procedures.
•Establish an emergency communication method (notification system, phone tree, etc.).
•Identify a high ground meeting place.
•Elevate equipment, and valuable/perishable items off of the floor.
•Store all your important documents in labeled sealed plastic bags.
•Take photos of key areas and critical items. Keep these on a cloud backup.
•Keep a cloud backup of copies from your important documents.
•Keep cash on hand for use after the flood if needed.
•Take all necessary steps to prevent the release of dangerous chemicals that might be stored on your property.
•Use plugs to prevent floodwater from backing up into sewer drains, or install flood vents or flood proof barriers.  
•Stay tuned to local media and community messaging.


•Turn off the gas and electrical prior to leaving the property.
trans-unit.target:
The following guidelines will help you be prepared for a flooding event:
•Develop and review an Emergency Plan.

•Locate gas main and electrical shut-offs and anchor all fuel tanks.
•If time allows, assemble and use sandbags in areas prone to flooding.
•Contact your insurance broker to discuss policy, coverage and claims procedures.
•Establish an emergency communication method (notification system, phone tree, etc.).
•Identify a high ground meeting place.
•Elevate equipment, and valuable/perishable items off of the floor.
•Store all your important documents in labeled sealed plastic bags.
•Take photos of key areas and critical items. Keep these on a cloud backup.
•Keep a cloud backup of copies from your important documents.
•Keep cash on hand for use after the flood if needed.
•Take all necessary steps to prevent the release of dangerous chemicals that might be stored on your property.
•Use plugs to prevent floodwater from backing up into sewer drains, or install flood vents or flood proof barriers.  
•Stay tuned to local media and community messaging.


•Turn off the gas and electrical prior to leaving the property.

trans-unit.source: Report floods easily and know info about other floods in parts of your city
trans-unit.target: Report floods easily and know info about other floods in parts of your city

trans-unit.source: Request is timed out. Do you want to try again?
trans-unit.target: Request is timed out. Do you want to try again?

trans-unit.source: Personal safety is paramount. Stay tuned to local media and evacuate when required
trans-unit.target: Personal safety is paramount. Stay tuned to local media and evacuate when required

trans-unit.source: Inspect foundations for cracks and other significant damage, paying particular attention to retaining walls. Take pictures of all damage
trans-unit.target: Inspect foundations for cracks and other significant damage, paying particular attention to retaining walls. Take pictures of all damage

trans-unit.source: Begin cleanup as soon as possible to prevent further damage to the property and to reduce opportunities for mosquitoes and other problems from standing water
trans-unit.target: Begin cleanup as soon as possible to prevent further damage to the property and to reduce opportunities for mosquitoes and other problems from standing water

trans-unit.source: Cordon off damaged areas until a determination is made regarding safety
trans-unit.target: Cordon off damaged areas until a determination is made regarding safety

trans-unit.source: Clean and disinfect everything that got wet. Mud left from floodwater can contain sewage and chemicals
trans-unit.target: Clean and disinfect everything that got wet. Mud left from floodwater can contain sewage and chemicals

trans-unit.source: Contact insurance broker to verbally report damage so that an adjuster can be sent to the site
trans-unit.target: Contact insurance broker to verbally report damage so that an adjuster can be sent to the site

trans-unit.source: Remind people around you to take cell phones and chargers and emergency kits with them when they evacuate
trans-unit.target: Remind people around you to take cell phones and chargers and emergency kits with them when they evacuate

trans-unit.source: Listen to media reports to learn whether the community’s water supply is safe to drink
trans-unit.target: Listen to media reports to learn whether the community’s water supply is safe to drink

trans-unit.source: Avoid floodwaters; water may be contaminated by oil, gasoline or raw sewage
trans-unit.target: Avoid floodwaters; water may be contaminated by oil, gasoline or raw sewage

trans-unit.source: Be careful! Water may also be electrically charged from underground or downed power lines
trans-unit.target: Be careful! Water may also be electrically charged from underground or downed power lines

trans-unit.source: Be aware of areas where floodwaters have receded. Roads may have weakened and could collapse under the weight of a car
trans-unit.target: Be aware of areas where floodwaters have receded. Roads may have weakened and could collapse under the weight of a car

trans-unit.source: Implement damage assessment processes. To help ensure safety, assessment activities should only be performed in teams
trans-unit.target: Implement damage assessment processes. To help ensure safety, assessment activities should only be performed in teams

trans-unit.source: Use flashlights to examine walls, floors, doors and windows to ensure building is not in danger of collapsing. Listen for leaking gas lines
trans-unit.target: Use flashlights to examine walls, floors, doors and windows to ensure building is not in danger of collapsing. Listen for leaking gas lines

trans-unit.source: Ensure electricity is turned off prior to initiating assessment activities
trans-unit.target: Ensure electricity is turned off prior to initiating assessment activities

trans-unit.source:
•Personal safety is paramount. Stay tuned to local media and evacuate when required.
•Remind people around you to take cell phones and chargers and emergency kits with them when they evacuate.
•Listen to media reports to learn whether the community’s water supply is safe to drink.
•Avoid floodwaters; water may be contaminated by oil, gasoline or raw sewage. Water may also be electrically charged from underground or downed power lines.
•Be aware of areas where floodwaters have receded. Roads may have weakened and could collapse under the weight of a car.
•Check for flooded electrical circuits and submerged power lines or electrical appliances.
•Implement damage assessment processes. To help ensure safety, assessment activities should only be performed in teams.
•Ensure electricity is turned off prior to initiating assessment activities.
•Use flashlights to examine walls, floors, doors and windows to ensure building is not in danger of collapsing. Listen
•for leaking gas lines.
•Inspect foundations for cracks and other significant damage, paying particular attention to retaining walls. Take pictures of all damage.
•Begin cleanup as soon as possible to prevent further damage to the property and to reduce opportunities for mosquitoes and other problems from standing water.
•Cordon off damaged areas until a determination is made regarding safety.
•Contact insurance broker to verbally report damage so that an adjuster can be sent to the site.
•Initiate mitigation activities, to minimize damage to facility and contents.


•Clean and disinfect everything that got wet. Mud left from floodwater can contain sewage and chemicals.
trans-unit.target:

•Listen to media reports to learn whether the community’s water supply is safe to drink.
•Avoid floodwaters; water may be contaminated by oil, gasoline or raw sewage. Water may also be electrically charged from underground or downed power lines.
•Be aware of areas where floodwaters have receded. Roads may have weakened and could collapse under the weight of a car.
•Check for flooded electrical circuits and submerged power lines or electrical appliances.
•Implement damage assessment processes. To help ensure safety, assessment activities should only be performed in teams.
•Ensure electricity is turned off prior to initiating assessment activities.
•Use flashlights to examine walls, floors, doors and windows to ensure building is not in danger of collapsing. Listen
•for leaking gas lines.
•Inspect foundations for cracks and other significant damage, paying particular attention to retaining walls. Take pictures of all damage.
•Begin cleanup as soon as possible to prevent further damage to the property and to reduce opportunities for mosquitoes and other problems from standing water.
•Cordon off damaged areas until a determination is made regarding safety.
•Contact insurance broker to verbally report damage so that an adjuster can be sent to the site.
•Initiate mitigation activities, to minimize damage to facility and contents.


•Clean and disinfect everything that got wet. Mud left from floodwater can contain sewage and chemicals.

trans-unit.source: Please select a city to proceed.
trans-unit.target: Please select a city to proceed.

trans-unit.source: Birmingham Community Alert is a hi-tech messaging service for all residents and businesses in Birmingham providing emergency texts or voicemail messages during an emergency incident.
trans-unit.target: Birmingham Community Alert is a hi-tech messaging service for all residents and businesses in Birmingham providing emergency texts or voicemail messages during an emergency incident.

trans-unit.source:
Thank you for your willingness to contribute to FloodCitiSense. This document aims to provide you with adequate information on the data we receive from you, how we process it, and what we make available to the public in order to comply with the requirements of the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Our platform

The app you are using has been developed by the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA), Schlossplatz 1, 2361 Laxenburg, Austria as part of the ENSUF/FFG-funded FloodCitiSense project (No. 860918).
‍

What is “personal data”?

“Personal data” means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person, such as their name, contact information, their location at a certain time or IP address.
‍

Data processed by us

We are a scientific institute and process personal data for scientific purposes including environmental monitoring. We process personal data:

  • for which you have given us consent for a specific purpose (Art. 6 para 1 lit a GDPR), namely for the conduction of this scientific study;

  • that is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest (Art. 6 para 1 lit e GDPR), namely for the conduction of this scientific study; that is necessary for the purpose of the legitimate interests pursued by us or by a third party (Art. 6 para 1 lit f GDPR), e.g. avoiding legal disputes about rights in the contributions. If possible, we seek the explicit consent to the processing of data, in particular the disclosure to third parties (Art. 6 para. 1 lit. a GDPR). Below is a list of types of data the app collects. Please note that a copy of the data might be briefly stored in the server's memory for a short period. These data are temporarily stored apart from the database, managed and deleted automatically by the server's operating system and will not be accessed by us for processing, archiving, or any other reason. It is also possible through logging errors or general requests that submitted data be stored in one of the server's log files. These files are not publicly accessible and are not used for any processing, storage or data publication other than for resolving a possible software problem. These are technical necessities over which we have no control.
    ‍

Registration/Login/Profile update

We process the following data for registration, login and profile updates for a given user, all of which is stored in the FloodCitiSense database:

  • User identifier

  • First name

  • Last name

  • User identifier

  • Username

  • Password (encrypted)

  • Email address

  • Telephone number

  • Status of the user (active/deactivated)

  • Whether the email address has been confirmed

  • Last time the user logged in

  • Profile picture

  • Session ID

  • The city chosen by the user (Birmingham, Brussels or Rotterdam)

  • Number of times the incorrect password has been entered, reset each time the correct password is entered.

None of this information will be part of any publication (e.g. data products, scientific publications, etc).
‍

Log data

Whenever you use our service, we collect Log Data, or data and information (also through third party products) on your phone to identify errors in the app. Log Data may include information such as your device Internet Protocol (“IP”) address, device name, operating system version, the configuration of the app when utilizing our Service, the time and date of your use of the service, and other statistics. This data is used for identifying problems with our software and will not be published as part of the resulting data product.
‍

Cookies

We use first party cookies to provide essential site functionality. Cookies are small text files that are saved by your browser and temporarily stored on your device.
‍
Provided that you have consented to the use of cookies, our website uses Google Analytics, a web analysis service of Google LLC. (“Google”). Google Analytics uses cookies to help understand how the website is being used. In order to do so, information about your visit, including parts of your IP Address, may be transmitted, stored and processed on a Google server in the USA or another non-EU state.
‍
You can also prevent the placement of cookies through the settings of your browser or by downloading and installing the browser plug-in available at the following link:http://tools.google.com/dlpage/gaoptout?hl=de.
‍

Submitting your incident reports

We use first party cookies to provide essential site functionality. Cookies are small text files that are saved by your browser and temporarily stored on your device.When you submit your incident report, the app accesses and processes the data you collected, and some additional information we use for assessing the quality of your contribution and for reproducing technical problems in case of an error. The following data are sent to the server and stored:

  • User ID

  • User display name

  • User email address

  • User position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

  • Device and app information:
    > Version of FloodCitiSense app
    > Smartphone operating system and version
    > Device name (brand and model)
    > Device serial number
    > Language setting of the device

  • Information on the incident:
    > Incident ID
    > The city chosen by the user (Birmingham, Brussels or Rotterdam)
    > Type of rain
    > Type of flooding
    > Sign of damage
    > Sign of obstruction
    > Types of space flooded
    > Flood extent
    > Flood depth
    > Frequency of flood
    > Water clarity
    > Are you impacted
    > Date and time the report was made
    > Date and time the report was uploaded
    > Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

  • Information per photo submitted:
    > The submitted media file (photo)
    > TenantId - City Id
    > Time and date when the photo was taken
    > Compass direction of the photo
    > Tilt angle of the photo
    > Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)
    ‍

Information on contributions

On the map screen, we process information on submitted reports that are within the currently displayed map view. Since this usually shows your current location, it implicitly uses your current location (latitude and longitude). This information is processed even when you are neither logged in nor registered as a user. For this purpose, we access the following data:

  • User ID

  • Location (Latitude, Longitude)

  • Bounding coordinates for the part of the map currently shown in the app

However, we do not permanently store this information.

Data storage

The data from the FloodCitiSense application are stored and maintained on state-of-the-art web service environments hosted on rented servers at Hetzner Online GmbH, Industriestrasse 25, 91710 Gunzenhausen, Germany. We do not provide any means to access data for the hosting company other than the ways intended for every user. The environment is set up such that we restrict access to the database strictly to our trusted network and through APIs that let us choose exactly which data is accessible to which users.
‍
Regarding the use of cookies, please see above. Information about your visit, including parts of your IP Address, may be transmitted, stored and processed on a Google server in the USA or another non-EU state.
‍
After completion of the scientific project, all personal data are permanently anonymized so that traceability to individual users will not be possible unless users have explicitly asked us to safe and publish their personal data.

Data contributions

Please be aware that we rely on you to contribute data, which does not infringe on the rights of others. Make sure you follow the instructions for the campaign/project to which you contribute, and do not submit data that could violate especially personal rights, copyright or other legislation.
‍
By contributing data, you provide us with the information requested in the app/website, but we usually also collect additional data that allows us to trace technical problems and verify the quality of the contribution. Please see the details above.
‍
By contributing data, you grant IIASA a license to use this data. Please see also our Terms and Conditions, which are available from the app.

Third parties

Please note that we may employ the following third-party companies to facilitate our service:

  • Google LLC;

  • Hetzner Online GmbH.

These companies will have access to your data in order to perform the tasks we assign to them, as described above. However, they are obliged to not disclose or use the information for any other purpose.

Should you consent to the use of your username in our social media platforms, it will be visible in connection with the photos you submitted:

  • Facebook (www.facebook.com/, operated by Facebook, Inc.,1601 Willow Road, Menlo Park, California 94025; and Facebook Ireland Ltd., 4 Grand Canal Square, Grand Canal Harbour, Dublin 2 Ireland)

  • Twitter (www.twitter.com/, operated by Twitter International Company, One Cumberland Place, Fenian Street Dublin 2, D02 AX07 Ireland; and 1355 Market Street, Suite 900, San Francisco, CA 94103, United States)

Google LLC, Facebook, Twitter have their seat in the US and comply with “Privacy Shield”. According to a decision by the European Commission this guarantees an adequate level of data protection.
‍

Rights of the user

At any time, you have the right:

  • to request information as to which of your data we process (Art. 15 GDPR),

  • to request the rectification or erasure of your data (Art. 16 and Art. 17 GDPR),

  • to restrict the processing of your data (Art. 18 GDPR),

  • to request the transmission of your data (Art. 20 GDPR);

  • to file a complaint with a supervisory authority, in particular the Austrian data protection authority (www.dsb.gv.at) or the data protection authority at your place of residence.

You can instruct us to stop processing your data at any time using the contact data below. Even if you have agreed to the processing of data in the past, you can revoke such consent at any time (Art. 21 GDPR).

Should you have questions concerning your personal data, please contact us using the contact information below.
‍

Third party apps and websites

Our app and/or website may contain links to other websites. If you click on a third-party link, you will be directed to that site. Please note that these external sites are not operated by us and we do not have any control, nor assume any responsibility for their content, privacy policies or practices.
We therefore strongly advise you to review the Privacy Policy of those websites.

Contact us

If you have any questions about our Privacy Policy, do not hesitate to contact us.
International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)
Schlossplatz 1, A-2361 Laxenburg, Austria Tel: + 43 2236 807 0

Should you consent to the use of your username in our social media platforms, it will be visible in connection with the photos you submitted:

  • Facebook (www.facebook.com/, operated by Facebook, Inc.,1601 Willow Road, Menlo Park, California 94025; and Facebook Ireland Ltd., 4 Grand Canal Square, Grand Canal Harbour, Dublin 2 Ireland)

  • Twitter (www.twitter.com/, operated by Twitter International Company, One Cumberland Place, Fenian Street Dublin 2, D02 AX07 Ireland; and 1355 Market Street, Suite 900, San Francisco, CA 94103, United States)

Google LLC, Facebook, Twitter have their seat in the US and comply with “Privacy Shield”. According to a decision by the European Commission this guarantees an adequate level of data protection.
‍

Rights of the user

At any time, you have the right:

  • to request information as to which of your data we process (Art. 15 GDPR),

  • to request the rectification or erasure of your data (Art. 16 and Art. 17 GDPR),

  • to restrict the processing of your data (Art. 18 GDPR),

  • to request the transmission of your data (Art. 20 GDPR);

  • to file a complaint with a supervisory authority, in particular the Austrian data protection authority (www.dsb.gv.at) or the data protection authority at your place of residence.

You can instruct us to stop processing your data at any time using the contact data below. Even if you have agreed to the processing of data in the past, you can revoke such consent at any time (Art. 21 GDPR).

Should you have questions concerning your personal data, please contact us using the contact information below.
‍

Third party apps and websites

Our app and/or website may contain links to other websites. If you click on a third-party link, you will be directed to that site. Please note that these external sites are not operated by us and we do not have any control, nor assume any responsibility for their content, privacy policies or practices.
We therefore strongly advise you to review the Privacy Policy of those websites.

Contact us

If you have any questions about our Privacy Policy, do not hesitate to contact us.
International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)
Schlossplatz 1, A-2361 Laxenburg, Austria Tel: + 43 2236 807 0

trans-unit.source:
FloodCitiSense 2020

Privacy Policy

Version 0.2

Thank you for your willingness to contribute to FloodCitiSense. This document aims to provide you with adequate information on the data we receive from you, how we process it, and what we make available to the public in order to comply with the requirements of the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Our platform

The app you are using has been developed by the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA), Schlossplatz 1, 2361 Laxenburg, Austria as part of the ENSUF/FFG-funded FloodCitiSense project (No. 860918).

What is “personal data”?

“Personal data” means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person, such as their name, contact information, their location at a certain time or IP address.

Data processed by us

We are a scientific institute and process personal data for scientific purposes including environmental monitoring. We process personal data:

·       for which you have given us consent for a specific purpose (Art. 6 para 1 lit a GDPR), namely for the conduction of this scientific study;

·       that is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest (Art. 6 para 1 lit e GDPR), namely for the conduction of this scientific study; that is necessary for the purpose of the legitimate interests pursued by us or by a third party (Art. 6 para 1 lit f GDPR), e.g. avoiding legal disputes about rights in the contributions. If possible, we seek the explicit consent to the processing of data, in particular the disclosure to third parties (Art. 6 para. 1 lit. a GDPR). Below is a list of types of data the app collects. Please note that a copy of the data might be briefly stored in the server's memory for a short period. These data are temporarily stored apart from the database, managed and deleted automatically by the server's operating system and will not be accessed by us for processing, archiving, or any other reason. It is also possible through logging errors or general requests that submitted data be stored in one of the server's log files. These files are not publicly accessible and are not used for any processing, storage or data publication other than for resolving a possible software problem. These are technical necessities over which we have no control.


Registration/Login/Profile update

We process the following data for registration, login and profile updates for a given user, all of which is stored in the FloodCitiSense database:

•     User identifier

•     First name

•     Last name

•     Username

•     Password (encrypted)

•     Email address

•     Telephone number

•     Status of the user (active/deactivated)

•     Whether the email address has been confirmed

•     Last time the user logged in

•     Profile picture

•     Session ID

•     Number of times the incorrect password has been entered, reset each time the correct password is entered.

None of this information will be part of any publication (e.g. data products, scientific publications, etc).

Log data

Whenever you use our service, we collect Log Data, or data and information (also through third party products) on your phone to identify errors in the app. Log Data may include information such as your device Internet Protocol (“IP”) address, device name, operating system version, the configuration of the app when utilizing our Service, the time and date of your use of the service, and other statistics. This data is used for identifying problems with our software and will not be published as part of the resulting data product.

Cookies

We use first party cookies to provide essential site functionality. Cookies are small text files that are saved by your browser and temporarily stored on your device.

 

Provided that you have consented to the use of cookies, our website uses Google Analytics, a web analysis service of Google LLC. (“Google”). Google Analytics uses cookies to help understand how the website is being used. In order to do so, information about your visit, including parts of your IP Address, may be transmitted, stored and processed on a Google server in the USA or another non-EU state.

 

You can also prevent the placement of cookies through the settings of your browser or by downloading and installing the browser plug-in available at the following link:

http://tools.google.com/dlpage/gaoptout?hl=de.

Submitting your incident reports

When you submit your incident report, the app accesses and processes the data you collected, and some additional information we use for assessing the quality of your contribution and for reproducing technical problems in case of an error. The following data are sent to the server and stored:

·     User ID

·     User display name

·     User email address

·     User position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

·     Device and app information:

o   Version of FloodCitiSense app

o   Smartphone operating system and version

o   Device name (brand and model)

o   Device serial number

o   Language setting of the device

·     Information on the incident:

o   Incident ID

o   Type of rain

o   Type of flooding

o   Sign of damage

o   Sign of obstruction

o   Types of space flooded

o   Flood extent

o   Flood depth

o   Frequency of flood

o   Water clarity

o   Are you impacted

o   Date and time the report was made

o   Date and time the report was uploaded

o   Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)   

·     Information per photo submitted:

o   The submitted media file (photo)

o   Time and date when the photo was taken

o   Compass direction of the photo

o   Tilt angle of the photo

o   Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

·     Information per video submitted:

o   The submitted media file (video)

o   Time and date when the video was taken

o   Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

 

Information on contributions

On the map screen, we process information on submitted reports that are within the currently displayed map view. Since this usually shows your current location, it implicitly uses your current location (latitude and longitude). This information is processed even when you are neither logged in nor registered as a user. For this purpose, we access the following data:

  • User ID
  • Location (Latitude, Longitude)
  • Bounding coordinates for the part of the map currently shown in the app

However, we do not permanently store this information.

Data storage

The data from the FloodCitiSense application are stored and maintained on state-of-the-art web service environments hosted on rented servers at Hetzner Online GmbH, Industriestrasse 25, 91710 Gunzenhausen, Germany. We do not provide any means to access data for the hosting company other than the ways intended for every user. The environment is set up such that we restrict access to the database strictly to our trusted network and through APIs that let us choose exactly which data is accessible to which users.

Regarding the use of cookies, please see above. Information about your visit, including parts of your IP Address, may be transmitted, stored and processed on a Google server in the USA or another non-EU state.

After completion of the scientific project, all personal data are permanently anonymized so that traceability to individual users will not be possible unless users have explicitly asked us to safe and publish their personal data.

Data contributions

Please be aware that we rely on you to contribute data, which does not infringe on the rights of others. Make sure you follow the instructions for the campaign/project to which you contribute, and do not submit data that could violate especially personal rights, copyright or other legislation.

By contributing data, you provide us with the information requested in the app/website, but we usually also collect additional data that allows us to trace technical problems and verify the quality of the contribution. Please see the details above.

By contributing data, you grant IIASA a license to use this data. Please see also our Terms and Conditions, which are available from the app.

Third parties

Please note that we may employ the following third-party companies to facilitate our service:

·       Google LLC;

·       Hetzner Online GmbH.

These companies will have access to your data in order to perform the tasks we assign to them, as described above. However, they are obliged to not disclose or use the information for any other purpose.

Should you consent to the use of your username in our social media platforms, it will be visible in connection with the photos you submitted:

·       Facebook (www.facebook.com/, operated by Facebook, Inc.,1601 Willow Road, Menlo Park, California 94025; and Facebook Ireland Ltd., 4 Grand Canal Square, Grand Canal Harbour, Dublin 2 Ireland)

·       Twitter (www.twitter.com/, operated by Twitter International Company, One Cumberland Place, Fenian Street Dublin 2, D02 AX07 Ireland; and 1355 Market Street, Suite 900, San Francisco, CA 94103, United States)

Google LLC, Facebook, Twitter have their seat in the US and comply with “Privacy Shield”. According to a decision by the European Commission this guarantees an adequate level of data protection.

Rights of the user

At any time, you have the right:

·       to request information as to which of your data we process (Art. 15 GDPR),

·       to request the rectification or erasure of your data (Art. 16 and Art. 17 GDPR),

·       to restrict the processing of your data (Art. 18 GDPR),

·       to request the transmission of your data (Art. 20 GDPR);

·       to file a complaint with a supervisory authority, in particular the Austrian data protection authority (www.dsb.gv.at) or the data protection authority at your place of residence.

You can instruct us to stop processing your data at any time using the contact data below. Even if you have agreed to the processing of data in the past, you can revoke such consent at any time (Art. 21 GDPR).

Should you have questions concerning your personal data, please contact us using the contact information below.

Third party apps and websites

Our app and/or website may contain links to other websites. If you click on a third-party link, you will be directed to that site. Please note that these external sites are not operated by us and we do not have any control, nor assume any responsibility for their content, privacy policies or practices.

We therefore strongly advise you to review the Privacy Policy of those websites.

Contact us

If you have any questions about our Privacy Policy, do not hesitate to contact us.

International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)
Schlossplatz 1, A-2361 Laxenburg, Austria Tel: + 43 2236 807 0

  • Profile picture

  • Session ID

  • The city chosen by the user (Birmingham, Brussels or Rotterdam)

  • Number of times the incorrect password has been entered, reset each time the correct password is entered.

None of this information will be part of any publication (e.g. data products, scientific publications, etc).
‍

Log data

Whenever you use our service, we collect Log Data, or data and information (also through third party products) on your phone to identify errors in the app. Log Data may include information such as your device Internet Protocol (“IP”) address, device name, operating system version, the configuration of the app when utilizing our Service, the time and date of your use of the service, and other statistics. ‍
Provided that you have consented to the use of cookies, our website uses Google Analytics, a web analysis service of Google LLC. (“Google”). Google Analytics uses cookies to help understand how the website is being used. In order to do so, information about your visit, including parts of your IP Address, may be transmitted, stored and processed on a Google server in the USA or another non-EU state.

The following data are sent to the server and stored:

  • User ID

  • User display name

  • User email address

  • User position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

  • Device and app information:
    > Version of FloodCitiSense app
    > Smartphone operating system and version
    > Device name (brand and model)
    > Device serial number
    > Language setting of the device

  • Information on the incident:
    > Incident ID
    > The city chosen by the user (Birmingham, Brussels or Rotterdam)
    > Type of rain
    > Type of flooding
    > Sign of damage
    > Sign of obstruction
    > Types of space flooded
    > Flood extent
    > Flood depth
    > Frequency of flood
    > Water clarity
    > Are you impacted
    > Date and time the report was made
    > Date and time the report was uploaded
    > Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)

  • Information per photo submitted:
    > The submitted media file (photo)
    > TenantId - City Id
    > Time and date when the photo was taken
    > Compass direction of the photo
    > Tilt angle of the photo
    > Position (Latitude/Longitude as well as accuracy)
    ‍

Information on contributions

On the map screen, we process information on submitted reports that are within the currently displayed map view. Since this usually shows your current location, it implicitly uses your current location (latitude and longitude). This information is processed even when you are neither logged in nor registered as a user. For this purpose, we access the following data:

  • User ID

  • Location (Latitude, Longitude)

  • Bounding coordinates for the part of the map currently shown in the app

However, we do not permanently store this information.

Data storage

The data from the FloodCitiSense application are stored and maintained on state-of-the-art web service environments hosted on rented servers at Hetzner Online GmbH, Industriestrasse 25, 91710 Gunzenhausen, Germany. We do not provide any means to access data for the hosting company other than the ways intended for every user. The environment is set up such that we restrict access to the database strictly to our trusted network and through APIs that let us choose exactly which data is accessible to which users.
‍
Regarding the use of cookies, please see above. Information about your visit, including parts of your IP Address, may be transmitted, stored and processed on a Google server in the USA or another non-EU state.
‍
After completion of the scientific project, all personal data are permanently anonymized so that traceability to individual users will not be possible unless users have explicitly asked us to safe and publish their personal data.

Data contributions

Please be aware that we rely on you to contribute data, which does not infringe on the rights of others. Make sure you follow the instructions for the campaign/project to which you contribute, and do not submit data that could violate especially personal rights, copyright or other legislation.
‍
By contributing data, you provide us with the information requested in the app/website, but we usually also collect additional data that allows us to trace technical problems and verify the quality of the contribution. Please see the details above.
‍

Third parties

Please note that we may employ the following third-party companies to facilitate our service:

  • Google LLC;

  • Hetzner Online GmbH.

These companies will have access to your data in order to perform the tasks we assign to them, as described above. However, they are obliged to not disclose or use the information for any other purpose.

Should you consent to the use of your username in our social media platforms, it will be visible in connection with the photos you submitted:

  • Twitter (www.twitter.com/, operated by Twitter International Company, One Cumberland Place, Fenian Street Dublin 2, D02 AX07 Ireland; and 1355 Market Street, Suite 900, San Francisco, CA 94103, United States)

Google LLC, Facebook, Twitter have their seat in the US and comply with “Privacy Shield”. According to a decision by the European Commission this guarantees an adequate level of data protection.

At any time, you have the right:

  • to request information as to which of your data we process (Art. 15 GDPR),

  • to request the rectification or erasure of your data (Art. 16 and Art. 17 GDPR),

  • to restrict the processing of your data (Art. 18 GDPR),

trans-unit.note: Please verify the translation’s accuracy as the source string was updated after it was translated.

trans-unit.source: You are not allowed to select more the current selection.
trans-unit.target: You are not allowed to select more the current selection.

trans-unit.source: We were not able to determine your city. Please select your city again.
trans-unit.target: We were not able to determine your city. Please select your city again.

trans-unit.source: There is a problem verifying your account. Please login again.
trans-unit.target: There is a problem verifying your account. Please login again.

trans-unit.source: Not able to upload the incident.
trans-unit.target: Not able to upload the incident.

trans-unit.source: Location is disabled, Please enable it and try again.
trans-unit.target: Location is disabled, Please enable it and try again.

trans-unit.source: You have not entered a rainfall type or flooding type.
trans-unit.target: You have not entered a rainfall type or flooding type.

trans-unit.source: Your flood report has been uploaded successfully!
trans-unit.target: Your flood report has been uploaded successfully!

trans-unit.source: Please note that these reports are not used in real-time or for flood response. Instead they will contribute valuable information in post-flood analysis. If you are in an emergency situation, please call the emergency services.
trans-unit.target: Please note that these reports are not used in real-time or for flood response. Instead they will contribute valuable information in post-flood analysis. If you are in an emergency situation, please call the emergency services.

trans-unit.source: Thank you for contributing to FloodCitiSense!
trans-unit.target: Thank you for contributing to FloodCitiSense!

trans-unit.source: No data available from the server
trans-unit.target: No data available from the server

trans-unit.source: Status and editing of your reports
trans-unit.target: Status and editing of your reports

trans-unit.source: User Account is locked. Please try login after sometime.
trans-unit.target: User Account is locked. Please try login after sometime.

trans-unit.source: A password reset link will be sent to your email to reset your password. If you don't get an email within a few minutes, please re-try.
trans-unit.target: A password reset link will be sent to your email to reset your password. If you don't get an email within a few minutes, please re-try.
